I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed results-
based loan to the People's Republic of China (PRC) for the Shaanxi Xi'an Preschool Education 
Development Program. 
 
2.  The proposed program will support the Xi'an Preschool Education Development Plan, 
2019–2025 of the Xi'an Municipal Government (XMG) from 2021 to 2025.1 It aims to increase 
children's equitable access to high-quality early childhood education (ECE) in a rapidly growing 
megacity with enrollment below the national average for the PRC and with major disparities in 
quality between its urban and rural areas.2 The program will increase climate-friendly public 
kindergartens; develop teaching capacity; strengthen ECE financing, regulation, and supervision 
mechanisms; and promote and disseminate innovative approaches to improving ECE quality.3 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Strategic Context 
 
3.  Delivering quality ECE is a critical and cost-effective investment: quality ECE sets a strong 
foundation for learning, universal ECE helps make the entire education system more effective 
and efficient, and equitable ECE promotes economic growth and reduces inequality.4 Compelling 
evidence from the fields of neuroscience, economics, and developmental and behavioral sciences 
highlights the importance of the early years on human development outcomes and the long-term 
effects of ECE on labor productivity in an increasingly competitive global economy.5 However, to 
realize the full range of long-term benefits, both the accessibility and quality of ECE programs 
need to be improved.6 Only high-quality ECE is associated with children's development and 
learning, with especially strong evidence in the case of disadvantaged children. Process quality, 
including the quality of teacher–child interactions and developmental activities, is the primary 
driver of gains in children's development through ECE.7 
 
4.  Although the PRC has achieved remarkable success in alleviating poverty, reducing 
inequality remains a complex challenge. In 2018, just 1.7% of the population were below the 
national poverty line and 0.5% below the international poverty line,8 but the Gini coefficient has 
risen by 15 points since 1990, to 50, and differences in education are a significant driver of this 
inequality.9 The national government recognizes that promoting equitable access to high-quality 
ECE is an effective strategy for inclusive development, and that investing in the human capital of 
its future labor force is key. Ambitious national ECE targets have caused a dramatic increase in 
enrollment over just one decade, from 56.6% in 2010 to 83.4% in 2019. But the PRC has yet to

5.  Located in Shaanxi Province, the rapidly growing megacity of Xi'an is facing a major 
shortage of affordable kindergarten places, which threatens to widen the gaps in access and 
perpetuate inequality.11 Despite notable progress in developing ECE since 2010, an estimated 
45.5% of Xi'an's kindergarten-aged children (3–5 years old) were still unable to access affordable 
kindergartens in 2019, and pronounced quality disparities persist in the ECE system. This is a 
result of four key constraints: (i) insufficient places in high-quality public and affordable private 
kindergartens to meet current and projected demand; (ii) insufficient teaching capacity and in-
service training opportunities; (iii) a need for better planning, financing, regulation, and supervision 
of ECE, particularly in affordable private kindergartens; and (iv) a lack of innovation to improve 
the delivery of quality ECE. 
 
6.  Access to affordable kindergartens. With a gross enrollment ratio (GER) in ECE of 
76.0% in 2019, the public provision of ECE in Xi'an has been uneven and reached only 27.6% of 
the  360,549  children  enrolled.  Private  kindergartens  have  proliferated  to  meet  demand, 
accounting for nearly two-thirds (63.3%) of Xi'an's 1,839 licensed kindergartens and 72.4% of 
enrollment, but with considerable disparities in quality and affordability. Quality disparities are 
particularly evident between urban and rural areas—fewer than half (48%) of rural kindergartens 
are able to meet the rating system standards to be considered high-quality.12 Outside of the formal 
ECE system, about 87,395 children attended 636 unlicensed kindergartens in 2019. These 
children are not included in the GER. Informal kindergartens are of variable quality and, being 
unlicensed,  are  outside  the  government's  regulatory  supervision  system.  The  Ministry  of 
Education has required that all unlicensed kindergarten operations be either brought into the 
formal  and  licensed  ECE system  or closed  down.  Out  of  a  growing concern  over  access, 
affordability, and quality, Xi'an's 12 district and 2 county governments provide subsidies to private 
kindergartens that meet their standards, operate on a nonprofit basis, and keep tuition and other 
fees below a locally defined ceiling. These kindergartens are classified as affordable private 
kindergartens, and they account for 39.8% of all kindergartens and 44% of enrollment. 
 
7.  Teacher supply and qualifications. Women accounted for 98.5% of Xi'an's 37,939 ECE 
teaching staff (70% teachers, 30% childcare staff) in 2019. ECE teachers with a qualified teacher 
status certificate teach  as  either  regular  or contractual staff.  Childcare  staff  do  not  hold  a 
certificate. While public kindergarten teachers are required to hold a certificate, only two-thirds 
(66%) of those in private kindergartens do so. About 11% of teachers hold no qualification higher 
than a high school diploma, but this average mask urban–rural disparities: 28% of rural teachers 
have no more than a high school education (78.6% of teachers are in urban areas). Fewer than 
5.3%  of  all  ECE  teachers  are  backbone  teachers.13 Key  challenges  in  teacher  workforce 
development in Xi'an are (i) a dearth of opportunities for continuing professional development,

8.  Early childhood education financing and management. Financing for ECE increased 
significantly after the issuance in 2018 of the national ECE policy,14 but public spending on ECE 
in 2019 still represented only 0.2% of Xi'an's gross domestic product of CNY932.12 billion, which 
is lower than the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average of 
0.7%. The financial responsibility for developing ECE falls to district and county governments, 
which tend to allocate lower budgetary resources to ECE because they give priority to 9-year 
compulsory education. Average expenditure per ECE pupil in Xi'an reached CNY8,931 in 2019, 
but the gap between public kindergartens (CNY11,196 per pupil) and private ones (CNY8,067 per 
pupil) is considerable. Households bear the cost of ECE in the form of tuition and other fees in 
both public and private schools, although amounts vary dramatically. In an effort to reduce the 
individual burden of financing ECE, the government provides financial support for poor children 
at CNY750 per year. In 2019, nearly 88,000 children received this subsidy (16% of children in 
public kindergartens and 30% of children in affordable private kindergartens). A key management 
challenge in Xi'an is the inadequate use of information and communication technology systems 
for ECE planning, regulation, and management. Building a smart, integrated ECE management 
information system (MIS) is key to improving data-driven governance. 
 
9.  Innovation to improve quality. National and international best practices in ECE that are 
not  yet  fully  adopted  in  Xi'an  include  (i)  promoting  professional  learning  communities  and 
mentorship programs for teachers that pair experienced teachers with those requiring support, 
(ii) expanding parent and community engagement to promote positive parenting and a continuum 
of learning between home and school, (iii) strengthening inclusive education for children with 
disabilities in mainstream kindergartens so they can learn alongside their same-aged peers, and 
(iv) introducing play-based learning and child-centered curriculum reforms that recognize play not 
as an alternative to learning but as the main way that kids learn. National guidelines for play-
based pedagogy are not fully implemented, and private kindergartens in particular tend to be 
guided more by parents' preferences than by government policy, or by an understanding of 
developmentally appropriate cognitive, language, and socio-emotional skills for the preschool 
child. Stepping up parental outreach and disseminating ECE research results are integral parts 
of the innovation that is required to improve ECE quality. 
 
10.  As the share of under-5 children in Xi'an's total population increased from 4.6% in 2015 to 
4.8% in 2019, demand for ECE will continue to grow.15 An estimated 514,400 kindergarten places 
will be needed by 2025. To meet this demand, drawing on national and provincial ECE policies 
and following the implementation of several 3-year action plans, the XMG issued in July 2020 the 
Xi'an Preschool Education Development Plan, 2019–2025 (footnote 1). The XMG program's 
overarching goal is to achieve universal, affordable, safe, and high-quality ECE through (i) an 
ECE system of sufficient quantity and quality, with geographic balance and serving a public 
welfare function; (ii) an increase in the proportion of children in public and affordable private 
kindergartens; (iii) a strengthened teacher development system; (iv) an integrated ECE MIS to 
improve  management  and  accountability;  (v)  enhanced  financing  mechanisms;  and  (vi)  a 
mechanism for kindergarten cooperation and resource exchanges.

B.  Program Rationale 
 
11.  Rationale, strategic priorities, and lessons. The program rationale is to help the XMG 
address key ECE issues with a focus on areas where the Asian Development Bank (ADB) can 
add the most value. The program was developed in alignment with the strategic priority of 
supporting inclusive economic growth under the ADB country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 
for the PRC.16 Education is no longer a strategic priority under the current country partnership 
strategy (approved in March 2021), and the program, which experienced preparation delays due 
to COVID-19, will be the last stand-alone operation in the education sector. The program will 
support several operational priorities of Strategy 2030:17 (i) addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing inequalities—by improving access to quality ECE; (ii) accelerating progress in gender 
equality—by promoting women's labor force participation and creating new jobs and leadership 
roles for women; and (iii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and 
enhancing environmental sustainability—by adopting climate change mitigation and adaptation 
measures and managing seismic risk. The program reflects lessons from three ADB results-based 
lending (RBL) programs in the PRC’s education sector, and from ADB and other development 
partners' ECE experience.18 These lessons include the importance of (i) delineating the roles of 
national,  provincial,  and local  governments  as  well  as  the  private sector;  (ii) strengthening 
program monitoring and management systems; (iii) introducing effective models of ECE delivery 
and financing; and (iv) innovating through play-based pedagogical approaches, professional 
learning communities for teachers, and parenting education for caregivers (footnote 15). 
 
12.  Program modality. The nature of ECE reforms in Xi'an requires a comprehensive, 
system-based approach. The government's ECE reform agenda, which the program supports, is 
extensive, covering about 2,400 kindergartens, 31,900 ECE teaching staff, 12 districts, and 
2 counties. The government shows strong ownership of the program, providing 87.83% of the 
total  financing,  and  a  commitment  to  results-based  planning  and  management  for  system 
improvement and institutional strengthening. This has been demonstrated in ongoing education 
RBL programs in the PRC. RBL leverages counterpart resources under a single results framework 
and expands the development impact of ADB financing, which accounts for only 6.74% of the 
total program financing. The due diligence assessments provide assurance for the effective 
achievement of results through the program, and measures to strengthen government systems 
that will be used for program implementation are built into its design. Unlike a project loan where 
disbursement is expenditure based, the use of RBL will ensure a high level of emphasis on better 
service quality and capacity-building activities where ADB involvement adds particular value. 
 
13.  ADB's value addition. ADB will add value by (i) driving policy and system reforms aligned 
with the national ECE policy, (ii) promoting equity in the provision of ECE to address differential 
financing and quality, (iii) demonstrating effective models of ECE provision that differentiate rural 
and urban needs, and (iv) improving data management. ADB worked with the XMG to strengthen 
the program, introducing results-based management in the ECE system and a focus on quality 
and innovation. Drawing on more than 25 years of engagement in the PRC focused on policy 
support,  strategy  development,  institutional  strengthening,  capacity  building,  and  extensive

D.  Program Results 
 
15.  The RBL program's impact will be: universal, affordable, safe, and high-quality ECE in 
Xi'an developed (footnote 1). The outcome will be: equitable access to high-quality ECE in Xi'an 
expanded, with three disbursement-linked indicators (DLIs) (para. 21). There are four outputs.22 
 
16.  Output 1: Climate-friendly public kindergartens increased. The program will provide 
at least 50,000 new public kindergarten places across Xi'an's 12 districts and 2 counties (DLI 4), 
spatially distributed to match demand. New public kindergartens will comply with the Shaanxi 
provincial standards for green building labels and will satisfy the one-star green building standard 
to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.23 Climate change adaptation measures include stormwater 
management networks. The program will upgrade at least 50 existing kindergartens with energy-
efficient and environment-friendly materials, and supply better equipment with environmental 
protection labels to at least 200 kindergartens. 
 
17.  Output 2: Early childhood education teaching capacity developed. The program will 
(i) recruit at least 5,400 new teaching staff (95% to women);24 (ii) ensure that at least 25% of urban 
and rural teachers each year are able to attend different types of in-service training (national, 
provincial, or municipal short-term, long-term, or online programs) and report improved capacity; 
and (iii) boost leadership roles for ECE staff (DLI 5) by supporting at least 452 teachers (at least 
99% of them women) to become backbone teachers (master teachers, subject leaders, and elite 
teachers), an increase of 33.4%. This will bring direct benefits to women through better jobs, 
higher status, and increased eligibility for promotion. The 1,810 backbone teachers will each 
provide on-the-job mentorship to up to 20 less-experienced teachers each year, to reach about 
36,200 teachers. Innovations to improve ECE teaching capacity, including professional learning 
communities and improved capacity for inclusive education, are described in output 4. 
 
18.  Output  3:  Early  childhood  education  financing,  regulation,  and  supervision 
mechanisms strengthened. The program will strengthen the ECE financing system by ensuring 
that districts and counties provide adequate per-pupil financing. This output will improve the 
implementation  of  regulations  and quality standards  by  reducing the  number  of  unlicensed 
kindergartens (DLI 6). The program team will support better ECE data management by developing 
an  upgraded  and  integrated  ECE  MIS  (DLI  7),  key  to  the  goal  of  improving  data-driven 
governance. The ECE MIS will be part of a smart education platform that manages data on ECE 
pupils and their families, staff, and classes; and connects kindergarten facilities to enable better 
planning, supervision, and management of ECE resources and reporting of results. All data will 
be disaggregated by sex and ethnicity.

20.  Beneficiaries. The program's direct beneficiaries will be Xi'an's preschool-aged children 
(3–5 years old), expected to total 514,400 by 2025, and their families (especially mothers, and 
including  migrant  and low-income families).  Other  direct  beneficiaries will  be  an  estimated 
67,136 ECE teachers, childcare staff, principals, and administrative staff (52,442 staff in 2019, 
and an estimated 14,694 to be recruited), a very large majority of whom are women (90.7% in 
2019). Broader benefits to the economy and society are expected in the long term from higher 
labor productivity and less inequality thanks to improved ECE.

III.  SUMMARY OF ASSESSMENTS 
 
A.  Program Technical Assessments 
 
28.  The XMG's program aims to implement the national ECE policy (footnote 14) through a 
broad range of activities. Program technical assessments concluded that Xi'an's ECE system 
needs reforms to (i) solve ECE access issues beyond building new kindergartens; (ii) expand and 
strengthen teacher capacity, while reducing high teacher turnover; (iii) improve the management 
and supervision of public and private ECE providers; and (iv) support teaching staff in improving 
children's learning and developmental outcomes through innovative approaches. The program 
results framework, the DLIs, and the PAP incorporate these findings. An analysis of historical and 
predicted revenues, budgets, expenditures, and results in the past several years confirms that 
the program expenditure framework and financing plan is robust. Due diligence confirms that the 
program design and implementation arrangements are sound, the results framework is designed 
well, and the DLIs are critical indicators for achieving program results. 
 
29.  Economic  analysis.  The  core  economic  rationale  for  investing  in  ECE  lies  in  its 
empirically demonstrated positive impact on labor productivity, economic growth, and inequality 
(para. 3). Returns to investment in ECE are high: one landmark long-term study of a program for 
children aged 3–5 years in the United States estimated a return to society of about $7–$12 for 
each $1 invested.27 In the PRC, an analysis of the long-term benefits of participation in ECE in 
Yunnan Province finds strong statistical evidence that ECE is associated with higher educational 
attainment and greater labor force participation (footnote 6). Public intervention in ECE is justified 
because of equity concerns regarding the quality and cost of ECE. Inequality starts in early 
childhood and tends to widen as children get older. Ample empirical evidence shows that the 
benefits of quality ECE last a lifetime, providing a basis for human capital accumulation, higher 
labor productivity, and increased earnings. Research also shows that ECE boosts women's 
employment options and reduces the intergenerational transmission of inequality and poverty. 
Other economic benefits of the program will result from (i) the engagement of 14,694 additional 
teaching, administrative, and other kindergarten staff; (ii) stronger employment prospects and 
livelihoods of parents and other persons released from full-time care duties; and (iii) reduced 
greenhouse gas emissions thanks to building and operating more climate-friendly kindergartens. 
 
30.  Poverty, social, and gender. The program has a strong social inclusion and gender focus 
and is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. It will particularly benefit vulnerable children 
from  low-income  and migrant  families,  children  with  disabilities,  or children  whose  primary 
caregivers are not their parents. Gender analysis revealed that childcare tasks are shared by both 
parents in just 30% of households, because of both traditional gender roles and a low awareness 
of the importance of fathers' involvement in their young children's socialization. As a result of 
gender stereotypes, men are underrepresented in the ECE workforce. Women account for 98.5% 
of teaching staff, but for only 91.5% of principals, and teachers lack access to in-service training. 
Teacher  turnover  is  an  issue,  especially  in  private  kindergartens.  The  awareness  of  the 
importance of gender sensitivity in the design of the curriculum, teaching and learning materials, 
and evaluation is rather low. The program results framework, design and monitoring framework, 
DLIs, and PAP set gender targets and actions, such as creating skilled jobs for women as teachers, 
expanding access to different types of in-service training, expanding leadership roles for women 
as  backbone  teachers,  involving  fathers  in  parenting  programs,  ensuring  gender-sensitive 
curriculum and materials, and designing an MIS that includes sex-disaggregated data. XEB will

31.  Coronavirus disease  impact  and response. The coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19) 
outbreak in Xi'an was at its peak in January–March 2020, when all schools and kindergartens 
closed. Primary and middle schools were able to return to in-person classes by April 2020, and 
kindergartens reopened by June. Xi'an recorded zero cases of COVID-19 in kindergartens, which 
follow strict prevention and control measures. As of September 2020, with no cases of local 
transmission for more than 4 months, kindergartens were back to normal operations, while still 
fully implementing infection control measures and with contingency plans in place at all levels. 
COVID-19 has led to a new kindergarten design that includes more handwashing stations, 
upgraded sanitation facilities, and better ventilation systems, which the program will support. 
 
32.  Climate  change  impact  and  geophysical  risk.  The  climate  risk  and  vulnerability 
assessment finds the overall climate change impact on the program to be low, but identifies 
projected temperature increases, intense precipitation, and stormwater-related flooding as risks. 
Adaptation  options for the  kindergartens to  be supported  under  output  1  include  improved 
stormwater  management  practices.  Mitigation  measures  include  green  building  design  and 
operation to reduce energy consumption. By adopting one-star green building standards and 
increasing the green areas of kindergartens, the program will reduce greenhouse gas emissions 
by 9,631.09 tons per year.28 The program will also support energy and water conservation and 
environmental awareness activities in kindergartens. New kindergarten sites will avoid disaster-
prone areas. All facilities to be constructed will be designed in accordance with the technical 
codes and regulations on seismic design. The kindergartens will formulate earthquake emergency 
plans prior to operation. The program's geophysical risk is low.

The proposed program will support the Xi'an Preschool Education Development Plan, 2019–2025 of the Xi'an Municipal Government (XMG) from 2021 to 2025. It aims to increase children's equitable access to high-quality early childhood education (ECE) in a rapidly growing megacity with enrollment below the national average for the PRC and with major disparities in quality between its urban and rural areas.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.
